conclusion: To solve the problem, analyze the movement of the particle along the semi-circular arcs, calculate the distances traveled, and determine the average velocity and average speed.

The image shows a particle moving along two semi-circular arcs centered at points B and D, with radii of 1 meter. The particle starts at point A, moves to point B, then to point C, and finally to point D along the curved paths, taking a total of 5 seconds.
The particle moves along two semi-circular arcs, each with a radius of 1 meter.
The distance traveled along each arc is half the circumference of a circle with radius 1 meter, calculated as \(\frac{1}{2} \times 2\pi \times 1 = \pi\) meters.
The total distance traveled from point A to point C is \(2\pi\) meters.
The time taken to travel this distance is 5 seconds.
The average velocity is calculated as the total displacement divided by the total time. Since the particle ends up back at the starting point (A to C), the displacement is 0 meters.
The average speed is calculated as the total distance traveled divided by the total time, which is \(\frac{2\pi}{5}\) meters per second.
The average velocity is 0 m/s, and the average speed is \(\frac{2\pi}{5}\) m/s.
